column1: Conquerors Community Development Corporation_Various Community Events and Programs

column11: Follow the Next Steps to find out if this program has eligibility criteria.
column13: The Conquerors Community Development Corporation (CCDC) hosts Various Community Events & Programs that help to elevate the quality of life for the West and Southwest Philadelphia communities.  We host the 51st Ward Register Community Organization (RCO) Mondays 6pm-8pm and a number of other Community engagement events throughout the year with the following being held annually:1) Community Health Fair - A host of healthcare agencies provide access to a wide-range of information and services for our neighbors.2) Back 2 School Community Day - The CCDC partners with Victory Christian Center for our back-to-school event which includes refreshments, activities and entertainment for kids, parents and guardians. We provide information about programs and services for children, new backpacks, and school supplies.3) Senior Thanksgiving Luncheon - In partnership with the United Block Captains Association (UBCA) and Victory Christian Center, we host a Thanksgiving Dinner style luncheon for the senior in the neighborhood.4) Christmas at Victory Village - Through our annual Toy Drive at Victory Christian Center and with Coats received from the YMCA in partnership with Auto Dealers CARing for Kids Foundation, we provide a new coat, a toy, and book for children in need. This is a festive and lively event that includes food, music and entertainment for families during the holiday season.
column19: This program covers residents of the following cities: Philadelphia, PA.

column11: This program assists African and Caribbean immigrants and refugees.
column13: AFAHO's multi-lingual and bi-cultural case managers assist clients in mitigating the myriad of barriers they face in accessing critical health and social services which play a vital role in their successful integration, improved health, and ability to be self-sufficient. This program provides:- Behavioral health - Domestic violence awareness and support- Housing assistance and monthly food assistance- Elders' programming- Individual case management- Family case management
column14: Arabic, English, French, Kinyarwanda, Swahili, Yoruba
column19: This program covers residents of the following cities: Philadelphia, PA.

column11: This program serves people experiencing homelessness.
column13: Navigation Center offers service-resistant homeless individuals the chance to gain stability by offering to meet their immediate needs by providing basic human services.Services include:- Temporary shelter- Food- Showers - Season-appropriate clothing- Resources for other human servicesFor more information, please call the Outreach Coordination Center's 24-hour hotline: 215-232-1984.
column19: This program covers residents of the following counties: Philadelphia County, PA.

column1: Salvation Army Eastern Pennsylvania and Delaware_Comprehensive Shelters
column11: This program serves homeless individuals and families.
column13: Salvation Army shelters welcome all homeless who come to their door. Comprehensive services are available to single-parent families, single women, single men, married couples, children awaiting placement in a foster home, and dual-parent families.This program provides:- Temporary shelter These shelters offer spiritual and physical care, food, and shelter to people in need. They attend the total needs of the individual and are meant to be a kind resting place to help these individuals get back on their feet.
column19: This program covers residents of the following counties: Kent County, DE, New Castle County, DE, Berks County, PA, Chester County, PA, Lebanon County, PA, Luzerne County, PA, Monroe County, PA, Montgomery County, PA and Philadelphia County, PA.

column11: All families must be referred to us through the City of Philadelphias Office of Supportive Housing central intake.
column13: Families Forward Philadelphia offers an emergency family shelter, for families in need, that has 65 individual rooms. While obtaining housing is their top priority, they also encourage saving money - working with families to dedicate funds to rent, furnishings and day-to-day living expenses once they leave the shelter.This program provides:- A warm, safe environment- Nutritious meals- Case managementAdditionally throughout the day, workshops are available to prepare families for independent living, including parenting classes, life skills development, computer classes, money management classes, and much more.
column19: This program covers residents of the following counties: Philadelphia County, PA.

column11: This program helps people who are 12 to 17 years old.
column13: Youth Emergency Service (YES) offers immediate housing, respite, and support services to youth ages 12-17 facing housing insecurity or are unable to safely live with family. YES Services include:- Twenty four hour emergency respite and protection for youth ages 12-17- Telephone hotline and referral services as well as links to national runaway and homeless youth providers through national Runaway Safeline and National safe Place- Medical care _ examinations and follow-up- Counseling supports and referrals- Voluntary and confidential HIV testing- Linkage to The Attic for those wanting service for LGBTQ youth- Physical and sexual health information and supports- Referral to home based services for families- Education and recreation programming and supports- Title I tutoringYouth can be self referred, enter through the formal child welfare system, Department of Human Services, or through referrals from partner organizations throughout the county. Referrals come from family, school staff and other concerned persons.
column19: This program covers residents of the following counties: Philadelphia County, PA.

column1: City of Philadelphia-Office of Homeless Services_City of Philadelphia, Office of Homeless Services-Prevention, Diversion and Intake
column11:
This program helps people with income at or below 125% of federal poverty guidelines.
Must be experiencing a financial crisis and at imminent risk of becoming homeless. OR
Received a court eviction hearing notice or court-ordered eviction. OR
Received a notice to vacate from landlord. OR
Lack family and financial resources, placing you at risk for homelessness. OR
Have the ability to sustain housing after receiving assistance.
column13: The City of Philadelphia - Office of Homeless Services provides limited emergency financial assistance and/or emergency response for families and individuals displaced or experiencing homelessness and residents with court-ordered evictions.This program provides:- Mediation- Financial Counseling- Problem solving- One-time payment for move-in costs (security deposit, first and last month's rent)- Up to 12 months of rental assistance with housing case management- Emergency Housing (shelter)Assistance is available for residents displaced by disasters, natural and otherwise. Due to high call volume, OHS staff will return calls within 5 to 10 business days. Assistance is based on funding availability.
column19: This program covers residents of the following counties: Philadelphia County, PA.

column11: This program serves residents in Philadelphia county, PA.
column13: The Drop In Center strives to be free of judgment, allowing people of all backgrounds to come in and relax. The Drop In Center is in many ways the gateway through which participants are connected to the many services provided by PPP. This program provides:- Case management- HIV/HCV testing and counseling- Mail services- Legal clinic- Medical services- CRAFT (links participants to addiction treatment)- Specialized surveys - MealsThe Drop In Center is open five days a week and provides daily respite for clients from outside weather.
column19: This program covers residents of the following counties: Philadelphia County, PA.

column1: SELF Inc_Station House Intake Center Services
column11: We serve single men experiencing homelessness.
column13: Centralized Homeless Intake Services includes an assessment of eligibility and service needs of persons and families presenting for placement into emergency housing. If eligible, persons and families are placed in appropriate emergency housing, boarding homes, or other alternative housing. Services include:- Temporary shelter- Ongoing case management services- Assistance with obtaining transitional and/or permanent housing- Supportive housing for special populations- An optional savings program which allows households to save a part of their income for future housing expensesMental health assessments and referrals to drug/alcohol treatment, health services, children and youth services, legal services and veteran's services, etc., are provided as needed to clients of the program.- Connecting Services to other community resources- ScreeningIf you are currently experiencing homelessness, please call us during business hours. You must go through central intake for an initial assessment of your housing needs before placement into the homeless housing system.
column19: This program covers residents of the following counties: Philadelphia County, PA.

column11: For individuals facing homelessness in the Philadelphia area.
column13: HELP USA is there for those who find themselves suddenly homeless, and they provide them with safe, temporary shelter and the support they need to get back on their feet. They believe in a different kind of homeless shelter - one that is respectful, supportive, and treats each resident as a unique individual.This program provides:- Temporary shelter- Day care and afterschool care- Physical and mental healthcare- Navigating the system- Help find work
column19: This program covers residents of the following counties: Bucks County, PA, Delaware County, PA, Montgomery County, PA and Philadelphia County, PA.

column11: This program helps homeless men.
column13: The Coffee House provides a safe resting and sleeping environment for chronically homeless men who typically avoid shelter living.This program provides:- Overnight shelterAdditional services:- Warm meal- Beverages- Restrooms- ShowersIf you are interested in staying at the SJH Coffee House, report to at the corner of N. Camac and Race Streets at 10 pm.

column11: This program serves homeless men.
column13: My Brother's House program offers a safe heaven that provides pre-recovery housing and an array of supportive services to 20 vulnerable men with chronic mental illness and substance abuse problem. This program provides:- Temporary shelterIn addition to a safe place to stay, resident are provided with:- Meals- Social services
column19: This program covers residents of the following counties: Philadelphia County, PA.

column11: This program serves teens experiencing homelessness.
column13: Covenant House's Crisis Care Services are short-term programs where a homeless child's most pressing, urgent needs are met immediately. There is no requirement that a young person be referred through an official channel - they can come anytime, day or night.This program provides:- Shelter- Hot meal- Emergency medical care- ShowersThis program also provides:- Mental health care- Legal assistance During the intake process, kids share their stories with trained staff so their immediate needs can be identified and then a plan is created for the best way to support them.
column19: This program covers residents of the following cities: Anchorage, AK, Anaheim, CA, Hayward, CA, Los Angeles, CA, Oakland, CA, Santa Clara, CA, Washington, DC, Fort Lauderdale, FL, Orlando, FL, Atlanta, GA, Chicago, IL, New Orleans, LA, Detroit, MI, Grand Rapids, MI, Saint Louis, MO, Asbury Park, NJ, Atlantic City, NJ, Elizabeth, NJ, Jersey City, NJ, Montclair, NJ, Newark, NJ, New York, NY, Philadelphia, PA, York, PA and Houston, TX.

column11: Must be male and homeless Must have a referral from The Office of Homeless Services (OHS). This program helps people who are older than 17 years old.
column13: Outley House serves single, adult men who are experiencing homelessness and are between the ages of 18 and 70+ years old. Their staff work tirelessly to help clients get back on their feet and start along the path to independence.This program provides:- Help find housing- Temporary shelter- Case managementThey also offer:- Behavioral and physical health services- Education opportunities- Independent living preparation- Access to resources and community contacts
column19: This program covers residents of the following counties: Philadelphia County, PA.

column11: This program serves single men in North Philadelphia who are experiencing homelessness.
column13: Sunday Breakfast Rescue Mission strives to meet the physical needs of the homeless and hurting men in Philadelphia through emergency shelter services that provide safe beds and nutritious meals to their homeless guests 365 days a year. Services:- Temporary Shelter- Meals- Shower- Case Management Sunday Breakfast Rescue Mission includes an intake assessment of eligibility and service needs of persons and families presenting for placement into emergency housing. You must go through a central intake assessment before placement into the homeless housing system. To receive a bed, please arrive at 7:00 PM. Intake closes at 8:00 PM. You do not need to call ahead. Men are able to stay with us for thirty days at a time.
column19: This program covers residents of the following counties: Philadelphia County, PA.

column11: Centralized Homeless Intake assessment of eligibility required.
column13: Jane Addams Place clients are admitted through Centralized Homeless Intake Services operated by the Office of Supportive Housing at the Appletree Family Center at 1430 Cherry Street, 215-686-7150. You must go through central intake for an initial assessment of your housing needs before placement. If you are currently experiencing homelessness, please visit the intake center.
